metadata.title: Title 1 Choanoflagellate transfection illuminates their cell biology and the ancestry of animal septins 2 3 Short Title 4 Robust transfection in choanoflagellates 5 6 Authors 7

body_text.text: First described in the mid-19 th century, choanoflagellates inspired great debate regarding 39 animal taxonomy (James-Clark, 1868; Kent, 1871; Leadbeater, 2015) . The most diagnostic 40 morphological feature of choanoflagellates, a "collar complex" composed of a single apical 41 flagellum surrounded by a collar of actin-filled microvilli (Fig. 1) , was interpreted as evidence of 42 a special relationship between choanoflagellates and sponges, whose choanocytes (or "collar 43 cells") each bear a collar complex. Subsequent phylogenetic analyses and the discovery of cells 44 with a collar complex in nearly all animal phyla have revealed that sponges and all other 45 animals are monophyletic, with choanoflagellates as their closest living relatives ( Fig. 1) (Lang 46 et al., 2002; King et al., 2008; Ruiz-Trillo et al., 2008; Burger et al., 2003; Fairclough et al., 2013; 47 We observed that transfected cells resembled untransfected cells in their shape, motility, 133 and ability to propagate, indicating that transfection did not irreparably harm S. rosetta. 134

Fluorescence persisted through multiple cell divisions, yet the diminishing signal in daughter 135 cells indicated that transfection was transient (Fig. S6A) . Importantly, using flow cytometry one 136 to two days after transfection, we found that ~1% of the population was reproducibly 137 transfected, and fluorescence-activated cell sorting enriched this transfected cell population 138 (Fig. S6B ). This transfection frequency is comparable to high frequency episomal transformation 139 of the model yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae that ranges from 1 -10% (Schiestl and Electron micrographs have revealed two distinct regions in the nucleus: the darkly-stained 154 nucleolus positioned in the center and the surrounding, more lightly-stained nucleoplasm 155 (Leadbeater, 2015; Burkhardt et al., 2014) . As predicted, mCherry fused to either the carboxy 156 terminus of H3 or the amino terminus of the simian virus 40 nuclear localization signal localized 157 primarily to the S. rosetta nucleoplasm and was excluded from the cytoplasm (Fig. 3B , C) 158 (Kanda et al., 1998; Kalderon et al., 1984) . In contrast, the cytoplasmic marker EFL-mCherry 159 (Huh et al., 2003) localized to the cytosol and was excluded from the nucleus (Fig. 3D) . 160

Two of the most diagnostic features of the choanoflagellate cell are the actin-filled collar 161 and the flagellum, which is comprised of microtubules (Karpov and Leadbeater, 1998) . A fusion 162 of mCherry to the filamentous actin-binding peptide Lifeact (Riedl et al., 2008) Subunit IV revealed a network of mitochondria (Nunnari et al., 1997) that is enriched around the 186 nucleus and extends throughout the cell (Fig. 3G ). Taken together, these fluorescent markers 187 demonstrate new experimental capabilities to rapidly tag proteins and to monitor their 188 localization in distinct cellular compartments and locales. 189 190

A major motivation for establishing transgenics in S. rosetta was to rapidly characterize 192 candidate genes for multicellularity. Therefore, we investigated the localization of septins, a 193 family of paralogous genes hypothesized to contribute to multicellular development in S. rosetta 194 (Fairclough et al., 2013) . The assembly of septin monomers into higher order structures is 195 important for septin localization and for the conserved roles of septins in 196 regulating cytokinesis and cell polarity in fungi and animals. In animals, septins also function in 197 phagocytosis (Huang et al., 2008) , ciliogenesis (Hu et al., 2010) , and planar cell polarity (Kim et 198 paralogs interact directly through their G-domains to form heteromeric filaments, and these 202 heteromeric filaments interact with each other through the septin coiled-coil domains to form 203 higher order assemblies (Bertin et al., 2008; Garcia et al., 2011; Sirajuddin et al., 2007) . 204 S. rosetta expresses four septin paralogs, three of which have well-annotated genome 205 models in the current draft genome (Fairclough et al., 2013) . We started by examining the 206 localization of the S. rosetta septin protein SrSeptin2 (PTSG_07215), a septin with domains 207 conserved in human and fungal septins (Fairclough et al., 2013) that are necessary for septin 208 filament formation (Sirajuddin et al., 2007; Bertin et al., 2008) . Strikingly, mTFP1-SrSeptin2 was 209 enriched at the basal poles of single and rosettes cells ( The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. It . https://doi.org/10.1101/343111 doi: bioRxiv preprint opposed to the concave membrane at the basal end of S. rosetta where wild-type SrSeptin2 231 localized. 232
body_text.section: Transgenesis reveals septin localization in live S. rosetta single cells and rosettes 191

body_text.text: The basal and lateral localization of SrSeptin2 and SrSeptin6 in rosettes is reminiscent of 233 septin localization in polarized epithelial cells (Fares et al., 1995; Spiliotis et al., 2008) , in which 234 septins interact with the positive ends of microtubules that are growing toward the basal pole 235 (Bowen et al., 2011) . In choanoflagellates, microtubules radiate down from the apical 236 microtubule organizing centers (Karpov and Leadbeater, 1998) , with the plus ends meeting at 237 the basal pole of each cell, similar to the orientation of microtubule plus ends toward the basal 238 pole in animal epithelia (Meads and Schroer, 1995) . To examine if septins also interact with the 239 plus ends of microtubules in S. rosetta, we co-transfected cells with mTFP1-SrSeptin2 and the 240 tubulin marker α-tubulin-mCherry (Fig. 4G ). Fluorescence microscopy showed that septin 241 filaments intercalate between cortical microtubules at the basal pole of the cell ( laboratories. This method overcomes numerous barriers that prevented efficient DNA delivery in 252 our prior attempts using diverse methods, including standard electroporation, lipofection, 253 bombardment, and cell-penetrating peptides. A key breakthrough for this study was the 254 discovery that the extracellular coat surrounding S. rosetta might present a barrier for 255 transfection, which motivated the development of a method to gently remove the extracellular 256 material surrounding S. rosetta, thereby sensitizing cells for transfection. Additional 257 improvements to the transfection procedure, such as a step for promoting the closure of the 258 plasma membrane after electrical pulsation, were designed to address the unique challenges 259 that arise from culturing S. rosetta in sea water. Just as our method was informed by 260 approaches developed in model microeukaryotes (Chlamydomonas and yeast), the methods we 261 have established in S. rosetta will likely extend to aid gene delivery in diverse non-model marine 262

Overall, the gestalt of continually improving choanoflagellate husbandry (Levin 263 and King, 2013) , developing protocols for priming and recovering cells during nucleofection, and 264 extensively optimizing transfection based on a quantitative assay produced a robust method for 265 gene delivery in S. rosetta. 266

body_text.text: This work also provides a foundational set of vectors for expressing transgenes in S. 267 rosetta (Dataset S1). In these vectors, the expression of luciferase or fluorescent proteins was (Hartwell, 1971 ). In addition to their conserved roles in cell division (Neufeld and Rubin, 1994) , The ability to express transgenes in S. rosetta described here will accelerate studies of the 308 ancestral functions of animal genes that are conserved in choanoflagellates. We anticipate that 309 future work will build on this approach, eventually leading to the development of methods for The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. body_text.section: Transgenesis reveals septin localization in live S. rosetta single cells and rosettes 191

body_text.text: Cell culture and media preparation 319 S. rosetta was cultured with a single bacterial species, E. pacifica, that serves as a food 320 source (Levin and King, 2013) . Media recipes are provided in Table S1 . Cultures were 321 established from frozen aliquots by adding 1 ml of thawed cells to 10 ml of 0.2x High Nutrient 322

Media (Table S1 ). After the cells reached a density of 10 4 cells/ml, the culture was split 1:2 into 323 1x High Nutrient Media with a constant volume of 0.24 ml/cm 2 . After this initial split (denoted as 324 day 0), cells were passaged in 1x High Nutrient Media according to the following schedule: 1:4 325 dilution on day 1, 1:8 dilution on day 2, 1:16 on day 3. Subsequently cells were passaged every 326 day at a 1:24 dilution or every other day as a 1:48 dilution of cells. 327

Based on the recommendation from Lonza to use a medium with a low calcium 328 concentration for transfecting mammalian cells, we searched for a seawater recipe with a lower 329 concentration of calcium than the routinely-used artificial seawater made from Tropic of Marin 330

Salts (Levin and King, 2013) , which has a calcium concentration of 9.1 mM at a salinity of 35 331 g/kg (Atkinson and Bingman, 1998) . The AK seawater formulation (Table S1) that has been 332 used to culture marine algae (Hallegraeff et al., 2004) and dinoflagellates (Skelton et al., 2009 ) 333 and has a calcium concentration of 2.7 mM. We found that S. rosetta grows more rapidly in 1x 334
High Nutrient Media prepared in AK seawater rather than seawater prepared with Tropic of 335

Marin Salts (Fig. S2A) . Therefore, we switched to a growth medium based on AK seawater for 336 routine culturing. After optimizing the nucleofection protocol, we demonstrated that growing S. 337 rosetta in AK seawater also resulted in higher transfection efficiencies ( Optimized transfection protocol 377

FIGREF0.text: Kawai et al., 2010), and similar transfection frequencies are achieved in model 141 apicocomplexans (Janse, Franke-Fayard et al., 2006; Caro et al., 2012). 142 143 Fluorescent markers illuminate the cell architecture of S. rosetta 144 To demonstrate the versatility of the new method for transfection and simultaneously 145 explore the cell biology of S. rosetta in vivo, we designed a set of fluorescent reporters to mark 146 key features of S. rosetta cells: the nucleus, cytoplasm, collar, filopodia, flagellum, membrane, 147 mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum (ER). For each fluorescent reporter, the mCherry gene 148 was fused in-frame to S. rosetta DNA sequences encoding conserved proteins or peptides that 149 localize to specific organelles or subcellular regions in yeast and mammalian cells. To 150 benchmark each fluorescent marker, we compared its localization in transfected cells to cellular 151 landmarks known from electron and immunofluorescence micrographs (Fig. S7) (Abedin and 152 King, 2008; King et al., 2009; King et al., 2008; Sebe-Pedros et al., 2013; Leadbeater, 2015). 153

FIGREF1.text: highlighted the 163 parallel arrangement of straight microvilli in the collar (Fig. 3G and 3J), as well as filopodia 164 extending from the basal pole of the cell (Fig. 3G, lower arrow)(Karpov and Leadbeater, 1998; 165 7 Sebe-Pedros et al., 2013). In live cells, Lifeact-mCherry revealed the native structure of the 166 collar, which can be distorted in cells fixed for staining with fluorescent phalloidin or actin 167 antibodies (Sebe-Pedros et al., 2013). Lifeact-mCherry also showed details of actin filament 168 organization that have not previously been evident, such as the existence of actin filaments that 169 originate in the cell body and coalesce at the base of the collar to form each microvillus (Fig. 170 3G', upper arrow; improved immunofluorescence techniques also preserve these cortical actin 171 filaments, Fig. 1B). A fusion of α-tubulin to mCherry (Straight et al., 1997) illuminated individual 172 cortical microtubules emanating from the base of the flagellum to the basal pole of the cell (Fig. 173 3K', arrow) and allowed visualization of the rapidly beating flagellum in live cells (Fig. membrane marker, with a geranyl-geranylation sequence fused to mCherry (Wang 176 and Casey, 2016; Reid et al., 2004), outlined the entire cell, including the flagellum, collar, and 177 cell body (Fig. 3I and 3L), and faintly marked the Golgi apparatus (Fig. 3I', arrow). In live cells, 178 the cell membrane marker captured the formation of a phagocytic cup engulfing bacterial prey 179 (Fig. S8)(Dayel and King, 2014). The ER marker (Friedman et al., 2011), which included the 180 amino terminal signal sequence from the secreted protein Rosetteless (Levin et al., 2014) and a 181 carboxy terminal ER retention sequence from the ER resident chaperone BiP (PTSG_07223), 182 highlighted the continuity of the ER with the nuclear envelope and the distribution of ER 183 throughout the cell, including around vacuoles (Fig. 3F). A mitochondrial marker (Friedman et 184 al., 2011) with an amino terminal targeting sequence from S. cerevisiae Cytochrome C Oxidase, 185

FIGREF2.text: Fig. 4B and 4E) and at points of contact 210 between adjacent cells in rosettes (Fig. 4E). This mTFP1-SrSeptin2 fusion likely revealed the 211 native localization of SrSeptin2 in S. rosetta because septins visualized by immunofluorescence 212 microscopy in yeast (Ford and Pringle, 1991; Kim, H. B. et al., 1991; Cid et al., 1998; Haarer 213 and Pringle, 1987), Drosophila (Adam et al., 2000; Silverman-Gavrila et al., 2008; Neufeld and 214 Rubin, 1994), and mammalian cells (Spiliotis et al., 2008) display the same localization as 215 septins tagged with fluorescent proteins. 216 To investigate whether SrSeptin2 localized to the basal pole of cells might be part of 217 heteromeric septin filaments, we examined the localization of another septin paralog, SrSeptin6 218 (PTSG_06009) and found that SrSeptin6 displays the same basal localization as SrSeptin2 (Fig. 219 4C). Such colocalization (Fig. S9) and the sequence homology with septins that have previously 220 been shown to form heteromeric filaments (Sirajuddin et al., 2007) strongly suggests that 221 SrSeptin2 and SrSeptin6 assemble together at the basal pole. We further found that the basal 222 localization of SrSeptin2 requires the coiled-coil domain, as a complete deletion of the coiled-223 coil domain (SrSeptin2∆CC; Fig. 4A, D, F) eliminated SrSeptin2 enrichment at the basal pole 224 when expressed in wild-type cells. Unexpectedly, mTFP1-SrSeptin2∆CC formed ectopic rings 225 around vesicles in the cytosol in wild-type cells (Fig. 4D and 4F). The localization of mTFP1-226 SrSeptin2∆CC resembled the formation of ectopic septin filaments at convex membranes and 227 the depletion of septins at the concave membranes in the filamentous fungi Ashbya gosypii 228 (Meseroll et al., 2012) upon the deletion of the coiled-coil domain of the fungal septin Shs1p. 229Similarly, vesicles to which mTFP1-SrSeptin2∆CC localized have convex membranes as 230

FIGREF3.text: Fig. 4G). These 242 data are consistent with conserved interactions between septins and microtubules from yeast to 243 animals (Kusch et al., 2002; Kremer et al., 2005; Sellin et al., 2011; Spiliotis et al., 2008), 244 including at the plus-ends of microtubules in choanoflagellates and animal epithelia (Bowen et 245 al., our growing knowledge of S. rosetta biology with a rigorous 249 characterization and optimization of each step in the transfection procedure, we have developed 250 a robust method for transgenesis in S. rosetta that can be easily implemented by other 251

FIGREF4.text: 268 placed under the control of native regulatory elements. From these vectors, we constructed a 269 panel of fluorescently tagged subcellular markers that serve as references for monitoring the 270 localization of other proteins in S. rosetta. For example, through our pilot study of SrSeptin2 and 271 SrSeptin6, the use of these new transgenic tools revealed that septins localize to the basal pole 272 of choanoflagellates, mirroring their localization in animal epithelial cells (Spiliotis et al., 2008; 273 Fares et al., 1995). 274 Observing septin localization in S. rosetta contributes to our understanding of how septin 275 functions evolved prior to the evolution of an epithelium in stem animals. A hallmark of animal 276 epithelia is tightly connected cells that each have an apical and basal pole comprised of distinct 277 lipids, proteins, and cytoskeletal structures (Rodriguez-Boulan and Macara, 2014). Septins help 278 shape epithelia and other types of cells by serving as buttresses (Tanaka-Takiguchi et al., 2009; 279 Tooley et al., 2009) and diffusion barriers (Barral et al., 2000; Takizawa et al., 2000; Hu et al., 280 2010) for membranes that have distinct geometries (Bridges et al., 2016; Cannon et al., 2018) 281 and lipid compositions (Casamayor and Snyder, 2003; Tanaka-Takiguchi et al., 2009; Bertin et 282 al., 2010; Bridges et al., 2014) and by interacting with microtubules (Spiliotis, 2010) and 283 filamentous actin (Mavrakis et al., 2014). While comparisons between animals and fungi have 284 revealed conserved functions of septins in cell organization (Spiliotis and Gladfelter, 2012), the 285 divergence of the lineages that gave rise to fungi and animals over one billion years ago 286 (Parfrey et al., 2011) resulted in important differences in fungal and animal cell biology (Stajich 287 et al., 2009). In fungi, septins facilitate polarized cell growth toward the new daughter cell (Kim 288 et al., 1991; Berepiki and Read, 2013), compartmentalize connected daughter cells (Barral et 289 al., 2000; Takizawa et al., 2000; Helfer and Gladfelter, 2006) , and mediate cytokinesis 290

FIGREF5.text: 291 animal septins have specific functions in epithelia that maintain apical-basal polarity (Spiliotis et 292 al., 2008), planar cell polarity (Kim et al., 2010), intercellular adhesion (Kim, J. and Cooper, 293 2018; Park et al., 2015) , and ciliogenesis (Hu et al., 2010; Kim et al., 2010). The basal 294 localization of septins in S. rosetta suggests that septin filaments organize a distinct region at 295 end of the cell, perhaps supporting intercellular contacts at the basal ends of cells in 296 rosettes (Fig. 4E). Consistent with this hypothesis is the observation that the Rosetteless 297 protein, which is necessary for rosette development, localizes to the basal end of cells prior to 298 secretion into the interior of rosettes where the basal ends of cells meet (Levin et al., 2014). 299 Continued study of septin function in S. rosetta will establish the mechanisms by which septins 300 facilitate multicellular development, and further comparisons with non-metazoan holozoans with 301 recently established transgenic methods, such as Capsaspora owczarzaki (Parra-Acero et al., 302 2018) and Creolimax fragrantissima (Suga and Ruiz-Trillo, 2013), will provide further insights 303 into the ancestral functions of septins. 304 Previous analyses of gene function in choanoflagellates relied on custom antibodies 305 (Abedin and King, 2008; Young et al., 2011; Burkhardt et al., 2014; Levin et al., 2014), laborious 306 forward genetic screens (Levin et al., 2014), and in vitro biochemistry (Burkhardt et al., 2014). 307

FIGREF6.text: 310 stable transgenesis and genome editing in S. rosetta. Combining an expanded repertoire of 311 approaches for investigating gene function in-depth in S. rosetta with comparisons to other 312 experimentally-tractable choanoflagellates (Li et al., 2018; Richter et al., 2018) and non-313 choanozoans (Suga and Ruiz-Trillo, 2013; Parra-Acero et al., 2018) promises to yield 314 increasingly mechanistic insights into the ancestry of animal cell biology.

FIGREF7.text: Fig. S2B) than growing 338 S. rosetta in seawater prepared with Tropic of Marin Salts. 339 340 Reporter plasmid design and molecular cloning 341 Dataset S1 lists the complete inventory of engineered plasmids with a summary of 342 primers, cloning methods, and annotations for constructing each plasmid. Complete plasmid 343 sequences and plasmids have also been deposited at Addgene 344 (http://www.addgene.org/Nicole_King). Below is a brief summary of considerations for designing 345 plasmids, and a more detailed description of standard molecular cloning methods for 346 engineering plasmids can be found in the Supplementary Information. 347 Cloning regulatory regions from S. rosetta genes. Because we had no previous 348 knowledge about the architecture of choanoflagellate regulatory regions, we aimed to clone as 349 slightly larger than the mean intergenic distance of 885 bp (Sebe-Pedros et al., 351 2017). Of necessity, the cloned intergenic sequences reported here were shorter to avoid 352 repetitive CA and GT sequences that were present before the putative promoter and after the 353 3'-UTR, respectively. To increase the specificity of primers, we designed the primers to anneal 354 to regions with a GC content ≤ 50%, as the S. rosetta genome is 56% GC. Ultimately, the 355 cloned regions that encompass the promoter and the 5'-UTR ranged in size from 550 bp to 356 1095 bp and those encompassing the 3'UTR ranged from 200 bp to 807 bp. 357 Synthetic gene design. Synthetic reporter genes (nanoluc and the genes encoding 358 diverse fluorescent proteins listed in Supplementary File 1) were codon optimized to match the 359 codon usage of the set of highly expressed intron-less genes listed in Fig. S1, as codon usage 360 can be biased for highly expressed genes (Hiraoka et al., 2009). A codon usage table (Dataset 361 S2) was generated from the coding sequences of highly expressed intronless genes (Dataset 362 S2A) and from all coding sequences (Dataset S2B) using the 'cusp' tool in Emboss (Rice et al., 363 2000). The codon usage table was then used to generate a codon optimized DNA sequence for 364 each target protein sequence with the 'backtranseq' tool on Emboss. The DNA sequences were 365 further edited by making synonymous substitutions with less frequently used codons to change 366 restriction enzyme sites and to remove repetitive sequences. Finally, sequences were added to 367 the ends of these designed genes for cloning with restriction enzymes or Gibson assembly. The 368 engineered reporter gene sequences are available through Addgene (Dataset S1; 369 http://www.addgene.org/Nicole_King). 370 Subcellular marker design. Dataset S3 provides the amino acid sequences for all of the 371 subcellular markers reported in Fig. 3. To ensure that the fluorescent protein tag for each 372 marker would not interfere with the functions of proteins or peptides that determine localization, 373 some of the constructs were engineered to have a flexible linker sequence (SGGSGGS) 374 separating the fluorescent protein and the localization signals. 375 376

FIGREF8.text: and detailed protocols for reagent preparation and 378 transfection are available at protocols.io at the following link: 379 http://www.protocols.io/groups/king-lab 380 Culture. Two days prior to transfection, a culture flask (Corning, Cat. No. 353144) was 381 seeded with S. rosetta at a density of 5,000 cells/ml in 200 ml of 1x High Nutrient Media. The 382 supplemented with 2 mg of frozen E. pacifica by resuspending a 10 mg pellet of 383 flash-frozen E. pacifica in 1 ml of media and then adding 200 µl of the resuspended pellet to the 384 culture of S. rosetta. 385Wash. After 36-48 hours of growth, bacteria were washed away from S. rosetta cells 386 through three consecutive rounds of centrifugation and resuspension in sterile AK seawater. 387The culture flask was vigorously shaken for 30 sec to homogenize the 200 ml that was seeded 388 two days prior (see above) and then transferred to 50 ml conical tubes and spun for 5 min at 389 2000 x g and 22°C. The supernatant was removed with a serological pipette, and residual 390 media was removed with a fine tip transfer pipette. The cell pellets were resuspended in a total 391 volume of 100 ml of AK seawater, vigorously shaken in their conical tubes for 30 sec, and then 392 centrifuged for 5 min at 2200 x g and 22°C. The supernatant was removed as before.Each cell 393 pellet was resuspended in 50 ml of AK seawater, vigorously shaken for 30 sec, and centrifuged 394 for 5 min at 2400 x g and 22°C. After the supernatant was removed, the cells were resuspended 395 in a total volume of 100 µl of AK seawater. A 100-fold dilution of cells was counted on a Luna-FL 396 automated cell counter (Logos Biosystems) and the remaining cells were diluted to a final 397 concentration of 5x10 7 choanoflagellate cells/ml. The resuspended cells were divided into 100 µl 398 aliquots with 5x10 6 cells per aliquot to immediately prime cells in the next step. A 200 ml culture 399 typically yields 6-8 aliquots of cells. 400 Prime. After washing away bacteria, each aliquot of S. rosetta cells was incubated in 401 priming buffer to remove the extracellular material coating the cell. The 100 µl aliquots that 402 contained 5x10 6 cells were centrifuged for 5 min at 800 x g and at room temperature. The 403 supernatant was removed with a fine tip micropipette. Cells were resuspended in 100 µl of 404 priming buffer (40 mM HEPES-KOH, pH 7.5; 34 mM Lithium Citrate; 50 mM L-Cysteine; 15% 405 (w/v) PEG 8000; and 1 µM papain) and then incubated for 30 min. Priming was quenched by 406 adding 2 µl of 50 mg/ml bovine serum albumin-fraction V (Sigma) and then centrifuged for 5 min 407 at 1250 x g and 22°C with the centrifuge brake set to a 'soft' setting. The supernatant was 408 removed with a fine-tip micropipette, and the cells were resuspended in 25 µl of SF Buffer 409 (Lonza). 410 Nucleofect. Each transfection reaction was prepared by adding 2 µl of 'primed' cells 411 resuspended in SF buffer to a mixture of 14 µl of SF Buffer; 2 µl of 20 µg/µl pUC19; 1 µl of 250 412 mM ATP, pH 7.5; 1 µl of 100 mg/ml Sodium Heparin; and ≤7 µl of reporter DNA. (Note that 413 higher volumes of nucleofection lead to lower transfection frequencies; thus, reporter DNA 414 should be as concentrated as possible, not exceeding 7 µl. Also, see below for "Note about 415 (Lonza), and the CM156 pulse was applied to each well. 418 Rest and recover. Immediately after pulsation, 100 µl of ice-cold recovery buffer (10 mM 419 HEPES-KOH, pH 7.5; 0.9 M Sorbitol; 8% (w/v) PEG 8000) was added to the cells, Recovery 420 buffer was gently mixed with the transfected cells by firmly tapping the side of the plate and then 421 incubating the samples for 5 min. The whole volume of the transfection reaction plus the 422 recovery buffer was transferred to 1 ml of 1x High Nutrient Media in a 12-well plate. After the 423 cells recovered for 1 hour, 5 µl of a 10 mg frozen E. pacifica pellet resuspended in media (see 424 above), was added to each well. The cells were grown for 24 to 48 hours before assaying for 425 luminescence or fluorescence. 426 Note about establishing transfection in non-model microeukaryotes. Establishing a 427 transfection protocol for S. rosetta required adapting several different transfection procedures 428 for a variety of eukaryotic cells to meet the unique requirements of S. rosetta. While the specific 429 details for transfecting S. rosetta may not be readily applicable to other organisms, the general 430 considerations and the process for optimization that led to the development of the transfection 431 protocol described here could inform efforts to transfect other microeukaryotes. Therefore, we 432 have included a summary in the supplementary information (See text and Figs. S10 and S11) of 433 the initial development and optimization of the aforementioned protocol. 434 435 Nanoluc reporter assay 436 To measure relative transfection efficiency resulting from different transfection protocols 437 and promoters, we performed luciferase assays on lysates of transfected cells. Cells transfected 438 with 2.5 µg of nanoluc reporter plasmids were pelleted by centrifuging for 10 min at 4200 x g 439 and 4°C. The supernatant was removed and the cells were resuspended in 50 µl of NanoGlo 440 buffer (Promega) and then transferred to a well of a white, opaque 96-well plate (Greiner Bio-441 one Cat No.655083). Luminescence was immediately recorded on a Spectramax L Microplate 442 Reader (Molecular Devices) with a 1 min dark adaption and 10 sec dwell time with the 443 photomultiplier gain set to photon counting mode. 444 Based on standard definitions from analytical chemistry (Harris, 2007) the detection limit 445

FIGREF9.text: given data point i and c is the calculated luciferase value. Second, the detection limit was 452 also determined as three standard deviations above the mean of eight replicate luciferase 453 measurements of cells transfected without any reporter plasmid, which resulted in the same 454 calculated detection limit. 455Reproducibility in luciferase assays was assessed by performing at least two independent 456 experiments on separate days with different preparations of 'primed' cells; data presented in 457Fig. 2, S2, S3, S10, and S11 represent one of the independent experiments. Within each 458 experiment from the same preparation of 'primed' cells, replicate measurements were 459 performed by setting up three to five independent transfections for each condition (shown as 460 black dots); bar graphs in Fig. 2, S2, S3, S10, and S11 show the mean values of the five 461 independent transfections with error bars showing the standard deviation. Before performing 462 statistical tests that rely on a normal distribution, luciferase data were transformed to a log-463 normal distribution by taking the base-10 logarithm of luciferase values as gene expression data 464 from luciferase assays display a log-normal distribution (Muranaka et al., 2013). 465 466 Flow Cytometry 467 To measure the percentage of cells expressing each of the different transgenes under 468 different transfection conditions, we used flow cytometry. Cells were transfected with 10 µg of 469 mWasabi or 10 µg of TagRFP-T reporter plasmids for flow cytometry because these 470 fluorophores produced the highest fluorescence signal upon illumination with the 488 or 561 nm 471 lasers, respectively. To prepare cells for flow cytometry, cultures from 10-12 transfections were 472 pooled 24 hours after transfection and centrifuged for 15 min at 3600 x g and 4°C. The 473 supernatant was removed with a fine-tip transfer pipette to avoid disturbing the pellet. The 474 pelleted cells were resuspended in 500 µl of 0.22 µm filtered AK seawater and then filtered 475 through a 40 µm filter. 476 Because a large number of bacteria were present in the cultures, S. rosetta cells were 477 gated based on the area of forward scattering signal versus the area of the side scattering 478 signal and the area of the forward scattering signal versus the height of the forward scattering 479 signals. To differentiate transfected cells from untransfected cells, fluorescence signal was 480

FIGREF10.text: benefit of transgenics is the ability to visualize protein localization and cell 489 architecture in living cells. To this end, we have established improved protocols for live cell 490 imaging in S. rosetta. Glass-bottomed dishes were prepared for live cell microscopy by corona-491 treating the glass for 10 s. Afterwards, 300 µl of 0.1 mg/ml poly-D-lysine was applied to the 492 glass cover (18 µl/cm 2 ), incubated for 10 min at room temperature, and then removed. Excess 493 poly-D-lysine was washed away from the glass surface with three rinses of 500 µl artificial 494 seawater. 495 Cells transfected with 5 µg of each fluorescent reporter were prepared for microscopy by 496 centrifuging 1-2 ml of transfected cells for 10 min at 3,600 x g and 4°C. After centrifugation, the 497 supernatant was removed and the cell pellet was resuspended in 200 µl of 4/5 Tropic of Marin 498 artificial seawater with 100 mM LiCl. Lithium chloride slows flagellar beating, as in spermatozoa 499 (Brokaw, 1987; Gibbons and Gibbons, 2013), to decrease the movement of cells during 500 imaging. The resuspended cells were pipetted on top of the poly-D-lysine coated glass-bottom 501 dish and adsorbed on the surface for 10 min. Lastly, 200 µl of 20% (w/v) Ficoll 400 dissolved in 502 4/5 Tropic of Marin artificial seawater with 100 mM LiCl was pipetted drop-by-drop on top of the 503 cells. The addition of Ficoll decreases flagellar movement by increasing the viscosity of the 504 media (Wilson et al., 2015; Pate and Brokaw, 1980) without significantly changing the 505 osmolarity or refractive index of the sample (GE Lifesciences). 506Confocal microscopy was performed on a Zeiss Axio Observer LSM 880 with an Airyscan 507 detector and a 63x/NA1.40 Plan-Apochromatic oil immersion objective. The mTFP1 and 508 mCherry fluorophores were selected for two-color imaging due to their high photostability and 509 minimal spectral overlap. Confocal stacks were acquired in superresolution mode using ILEX 510 line scanning and two-fold averaging and the following settings: 40 nm x 40 nm pixel size, 93 511 nm z-step, 0.9-1.0 µsec/pixel dwell time, 850 gain, 458 nm laser operating at 5% laser power, 512 561 nm laser operating at 3% laser power, 458/561 nm multiple beam splitter, and 495-

FIGREF11.text: , or 100x NA 1.40 Plan-Apochromatic oil immersion objectives. Green fluorescent 523 proteins were imaged with a 38 HE filter set and red fluorescent proteins with a 43 HE filter set. 524 Images were processed by applying a gamma factor and background subtracting fluorescence 525 channels in FIJI. 526 Note about titrating reporter plasmids. A titration of fluorescent reporter plasmids 527 showed that 10 µg of total reporter plasmid(s) best balanced transfection efficiency, brightness, 528 and a faithful indication of subcellular architecture. We caution that high plasmid concentrations 529 can result in the overexpression of fluorescent markers, leading to aberrant localization of the 530 marker and gross changes in cell morphology. Such artefacts can be avoided by performing a 531 titration to determine the best concentration of plasmid and recording images from cells with a 532 range of fluorescence intensities that result from any transfection. One of the best markers to 533 assess optimal reporter plasmid concentrations is the tubulin marker because of its distinct 534 localization that can be benchmarked with immunofluorescence. 535 536 Immunofluorescence staining and imaging 537 Immunfluorescence was performed as previously described (Woznica et al., 2016) with 538 modifications to better preserve features of the cytoskeleton. Two milliliters of cells were 539 concentrated by centrifugation for 10 min at 2750 x g and 4°C. The cells were resuspended in 540 400 µl of artificial seawater and applied to poly-L-lysine coated coverslips (BD Biosciences) 541 placed in the bottom of each well of a 24-well cell culture dish. After allowing the cells to settle 542 on the coverslip for 30 min, 150 µl of the cell solution was gently removed from the side of the 543 dish. It is crucial to leave a small layer of buffer on top of cells to preserve the cell morphology, 544 hence the 250 µl of liquid left in the well. All of the subsequent washes and incubations during 545 the staining procedure were performed by adding and removing 200 µl of the indicated buffer. 546

FIGREF12.text: 554Cells were permeabilized by washing the coverslip once with permeabilization buffer (100 555 mM PIPES, pH 6.95; 2 mM EGTA; 1 mM MgCl2; 1% (w/v) bovine serum albumin-fraction V; 556 0.3% (v/v Triton X-100) and then incubated for 30 min upon a second addition of 557 permeabilization buffer. After the permeabilization buffer was removed, the coverslip was 558 washed once with primary antibody, 50 ng/ml mouse E7 anti-tubulin antibody (Developmental 559Studies Hybridoma Bank) diluted in permeabilization buffer, and then incubated for 1 h in a 560 second application of primary antibody. The coverslip was gently washed twice in 561 permeabilization buffer. Next, the coverslip was washed once with secondary antibody, 8 ng/ml 562 Donkey anti-mouse IgG-AlexaFluor568 (ThermoFisher) diluted in permeabilization buffer, and 563 then incubated for 1 h after a second application of secondary antibody. Afterwards, the 564 coverslip was washed once in permeabilization buffer and then three times with PEM (100 mM 565 PIPES-KOH, pH 6.95; 2 mM EGTA; 1 mM MgCl2). The coverslip was washed once with 10 566 µg/ml Hoechst 33342 and 4 U/ml Phalloidin-AlexaFluor488 in PEM and then incubated for 30 567 min with a second application of Hoechst33342/Phalloidin. Finally, the coverslip was washed 568 once in PEM. 569To prepare a slide for mounting, 10 µl of Pro-Long Diamond (Invitrogen) was added to a 570 slide. The coverslip was gently removed from the well with forceps, excess buffer was blotted 571 from the side with a piece of filter paper, and the coverslip was gently placed on the drop of Pro-572 Long diamond. The mounting media was allowed to cure overnight before visualization. 573Images were acquired on a Zeiss LSM 880 Airyscan confocal microscope with a 63x 574 objective (as described for live cell imaging) by frame scanning in the superresolution mode with575 the following settings: 35 nm x 35 nm pixel size; 80 nm z-step; 0.64 µs/pixel dwell time; 561 nm 576 laser operating at 1.5% power with a 488/561 nm beam splitter, a 420-480 nm/495-620 nm 577 band pass filter, and a gain of 750; 488 nm laser operating at 1.5% power with a 488/561 nm 578 beam splitter, a 420-480 nm/495-550 nm band pass filter, and a gain of 750; and 405 nm laser 579 , helped with early tests of priming conditions. Introduction to Salpingoeca rosetta, an experimentally-tractable model 895 choanoflagellate 896 (A) S. rosetta and other choanoflagellates (abbreviated as 'choano') are the closest living 897 relatives of animals. (B, C) S. rosetta has a complex life history that includes single cells (B) and 898 multicellular rosettes (C). Immunofluorescence in fixed, permeabilized S. rosetta single cells (B) 899 highlights the diagnostic cellular architecture of choanoflagellates, including a single apical 900 flagellum (f) made of microtubules (white) surrounded by a collar (co) filled with F-actin (red) of 901 microvilli. Staining for tubulin also illuminates cortical microtubules (cm) that run in parallel 902 tracks along the cell periphery from the apical to the basal poles of each cell. DNA staining 903 (blue) highlights the choanoflagellate nucleus (n) and the nucleoids of bacterial prey (b) present 904 in choanoflagellate cultures. (C) In multicellular rosettes (stained as in panel B), the basal poles 905 of cells are oriented toward the interior of the rosette and the apical flagella point outward. 906 A robust procedure for transfecting S. rosetta 908 (A) A summary of the step-wise procedure to transfect S. rosetta with DNA plasmids. To 909 prepare S. rosetta for transfection, cells were harvested at mid-log phase and then washed to 910 remove bacteria (depicted as grey ovals). S. rosetta cells (depicted with an apical collar, 911 flagellum, and nucleus; n) were primed for nucleofection (step 1) through washing with a buffer 912 that degrades extracellular material. A DNA plasmid encoding a highly sensitive luciferase, 913 nanoluc, or a fluorescent protein was then transfected into the nucleus with a nucleofector (step 914 2). Immediately after transfection, the cells rested in a buffer that promotes membrane closure 915 (step 3). Finally, the cells were transferred into 1x High Nutrient Media prepared with AK 916 seawater for two days (step 4) before we assayed the expression of nanoluc or fluorescent 917 proteins from the transfected DNA. (B) Non-coding DNA sequences flanking the coding 918 sequences for S. rosetta elongation factor L (pEFL), α-tubulin (pTub), β-actin (pAct), and 919 histone H3 (pH3) genes drive the expression of a codon-optimized nanoluc reporter gene. 2.5 920 µg of pEFL-nanoluc, pTub-nanoluc, pAct-nanoluc, and pH3-nanoluc reporter plasmids were 921 each transfected into S. rosetta and the cells were subsequently assayed for luciferase 922 expression. Each reporter produced a luminescence signal that was at least three orders of 923 magnitude greater than the detection limit (dotted line) and significantly greater (one-way 924 statistical tests. (C) Systematically omitting each step of the transfection 927 procedure revealed critical steps for the delivery and expression of plasmid DNA in S. rosetta 928 cells. As a baseline for comparison, cells with 2.5 µg of pH3-nanoluc reporter (row b) produced 929 a luciferase signal that was three orders of magnitude greater than the background detected 930 from cells transfected without the reporter plasmid (row a). Omitting the priming step by 931 incubating cells in artificial seawater instead of priming buffer (row c), decreased luciferase 932 signal by over two orders of magnitude. Nucleofection without carrier DNA (row d) or the 933 application of the CM156 electrical pulse (row e) resulted in a complete loss of luciferase signal, 934 indicating that both were essential for successful transfection. Directly transferring cells to sea 935 water after nucleofection instead of a buffer that promotes membrane resealing during the rest 936 step (row f) decreased the luciferase signal almost ten-fold. Finally, despite the fact that most 937 prey bacteria were washed out prior to nucleofection, addition of fresh prey bacteria did not 938 appear to be necessary. Supplementing transfected cells with fresh prey bacteria at the start of 939 the recovery step had seemingly little effect on transfection success (row g), probably due to the 940 persistence of a small number of live bacteria throughout the nucleofection procedure. (D and 941 E) Fluorescent reporters mark transfected cells. Live cells transfected with a pAct-mWasabi 942 reporter construct could be observed by fluorescence microscopy (D) and quantified by flow 943 cytometry (E). Untransfected cells were used to draw a gate that includes 99.99% of cells, or 944 four-standard deviations above the mean fluorescence value (left). The same gate was applied 945 to a population of transfected cells (right) to categorize the mWasabi-population. Cells with 946 higher values of green fluorescence that laid outside of the mWasabi-gate are categorized as 947 mWasabi+. The efficiency of transformation, as quantified by three independent flow cytometry 948 experiments, was ~1% in a population of 1 million cells. 949 Fluorescent markers illuminate the cell biology of S. rosetta in live cells 951 Fluorescent subcellular markers expressed from reporter plasmids in live S. rosetta cells were 952constructed by fusing mCherry in frame to genes encoding localization peptides and proteins 953 (Datasets S1 and S3). Twenty-four hours after co-transfecting cells with 5 µg of a plasmid 954 encoding a subcellular marker fused to the mCherry protein and 5 µg of a plasmid encoding 955 untagged mTFP1 that served as a whole cell marker, live cells were visualized by 956 superresolution microscopy with a Zeiss LSM 880 Airyscan. The variation in localization of the 957

TABREF0.text: al., 2010). Septin proteins have a characteristic domain architecture with a diagnostic amino 199 terminal guanosine triphosphate binding domain (G-domain), and most septins also have a 200 carboxy terminal coiled-coil domain (Pan et al., 2007; Nishihama et al., 2011) (Fig. 4A). Septin 201
